text: A MAN in his 70s walks along a narrow stretch of grass separating a busy road from a railroad yard. The man walks purposefully, despite the hesitant gait and clouded eyes of a longtime alcoholic.

Now a bit dazed and slowed by fatigue, the man walks past sign reading BILLINGS CITY LIMITS. A state patrol cruiser pulls up in front of him, and a TROOPER gets out. EXT. DAVID’S APARTMENT BUILDING - DAY 3 A modest structure set against a bluff. INT. DAVID’S APARTMENT - DAY 4 DAVID GRANT - 40 - sits in a recliner in a sparsely-furni living room. He watches TV and drinks from a plastic bott of Mountain Dew. The doorbell rings. He gets up and opens the door. It’s his recent ex-girlfri NOEL with two suitcases.
Hi.
Hi.
Wow. Are you moving back in?
No, these are yours. I’m just returning them.
Right. Thanks. Do you want to come in? She thinks a moment before stepping inside and maintains polite distance. She notices a droopy plant.
David, you’re supposed to water that plant. It’s a plant. David goes to the kitchen to fill a container with water.
I’d like you to change your mind.
What does that mean?
You know what it means. I want you to move back in.
I just moved out.
So two years, and we’re back to dating.
I don’t know yet. We’ll see ina while.
Are we still having sex?
What do you think?
I think we are.
And then what?
Usually I fall asleep. Not in the mood for a joke --
I’ve got to go.
Are you saying we can’t be together again unless we get married?  Blue (10-12-2012) 3.
Get married, break up, I don’t know. Let’s do both. Let’s just do something. The phone rings. David and Noél wait in silence as the machine eventually picks up.
Pick up or call me back right now. It’s your father -- he’s gone crazy.
Oh, shit. He runs to pick up the phone. Noél starts for the door.
Hi, Mom. I’m here.
David, it’s your mother.
That’s why I said, “Hi, Mom.”
I don’t know what I’m going to do with him. I’m going to put him in a goddamned nursing home is what I’m going to do. I’m too old for this. As Kate continues, David waves a weak goodbye to Noél.
WOODY GRANT sits on a folding chair in a cinder-block off A SHERIFF leads David inside.
There’s the man of the hour.
The what?
The man of the hour.
I don’t know.  Blue (10-12-2012) 4. In addition to general confusion, Woody is deaf in one ea
So you told the sheriff you were walking to... Nebraska?
That’s right. To get my million dollars.
What million dollars?

I won a million dollars. He pulls a crinkled letter from his jacket pocket, which unfolds and labors to read. WOODY (CONT’D) “We are now authorized to pay one million dollars to Mr. Woodrow T. Grant of Billings, Montana.”
Let me see. Woody hands David the letter.
Your mother won’t take me.
(reading) Mega Sweepstakes Marketing. Dad, this is a total come-on. It’s one of the oldest gimmicks in the book. I didn’t even know they did this anymore.
They can’t say it if it’s not true.
They’re just trying to sell you magazine subscriptions.
It says I won.
So let’s mail it in. I’11 help you.  Blue (10-12-2012)

I don’t trust the mail with a million dollars. EXT. WOODY AND KATE’S HOUSE - DAY A modest home. Woody and David get out of David’s car. David pulls a ver full laundry basket from his back seat. They go inside the kitchen door. INT. WOODY AND KATE’S KITCHEN - CONTINUOUS KATE GRANT awaits them wearing a faded floral housecoat. 7 The house has a tired, 70s-era décor. David puts his basket i the laundry room at one end of the kitchen.
You dumb cluck. You pretty near gave me a heart attack!
Now just cool your jets.
This is the second time he’s tried to sneak out. I never knew the son- of-a-bitch even wanted to be a millionaire. He should have thought about that years ago and worked for it.
What would you do with a million dollars anyway, Dad?
Buy a new truck.
You can’t drive.
I‘1l get my license back.
Tell me when you do so I can stay off the road.  Blue (10-12-2012)
I need an air compressor too.
Are you still harping on that?
Ed Pegram still has mine.
That’s because he’s a thief.
He’s not a thief. I lent it to him.
Who's Ed Pegram?
Guy I knew back in Hawthorne.
When did he borrow it?
Seventy-four.
That’s almost forty years. He lives two states away. I’d say he stole it.
That’s why I need a new one. Woody heads down the hallway.
Where you off to now?
Lyin’ down.
He even sleeps with that stupid letter. He’s memorized it word for word. I didn’t think he could memorize anything anymore.
(opening the refrigerator) Hey, what’s with this casserole?  Blue (10-12-2012)

It’s lasagna. It’s still good. Take it. And take some bananas. I bought a whole lot of them yesterday. Your father makes me so nervous. You know what I’d do with a million dollars -- I’d put him in a home.
David works with a YOUNG COUPLE inside a soundproof DEMO ROOM. David and the man headbang to a rock anthem. The woman looks bored. Soon David leads them back into the showroom.
Like I say, you basically just test- drove a Cadillac or Rolls Royce or whatever. Wasn’t that awesome?
Totally.

But that’s not to say I can’t set you up with a whole lot more reasonable speakers that’1l still blow your mind if you’re worried the Wilsons are going to set you back too much. The way they design speakers anymore, you can’t make a mistake. The woman tugs on her boyfriend’s arm.
Great. I think, uh, I think we just need to discuss this and get back to you.
Here’s my card. Give me a call anytime if you have any more questions.
Thanks a lot.
Excellent, Mark, Janice. Pleasure.  10 Blue (10-12-2012)
Juh-neece.
Juh-neece. Sorry. David watches them go. They won’t be back.
David, your mother’s on line one. EXT. WOODY AND KATE’S HOUSE - DAY David gets out of his car and finds his mother near the garage.
Where’d they find him this time?
Way the hell out on King Avenue by the Albertson’s. I can’t take it anymore. Ross is in there trying to talk some sense into him. David goes into the --
-- where David’s brother ROSS watches Woody work on the engine of a very old Ford pickup. Ross has a sportcoat, and perfect haircut.
Hi, Dave.
Ross. What’s going on, Dad?
Talk to Ma and Ross. They seem to know it all.
I’m asking you.
Can't get her to turn over.
That’s because it’s been sitting there for ten years. 10 tie,  Blue (10-12-2012) 9.
I‘1l get her runnin’.
He still thinks he’s going to Lincoln to get his money.
Gotta get there by the 5th.

Hey Dad, how come you didn’t think of fixing the truck first or take a bus? Why’d you just start walking? Woody looks up a moment, thinks about that, then gets bac work. David leads his brother out of the garage.
Don’t pull his chain like that. The poor guy doesn’t know what’s going on half the time.
I cut the solenoid wire and stuck it back in. That’1l slow him down. And Mom’s right -- it’s time to think about a home. She can’t handle him anymore. It’s not fair to her.
He doesn’t need a nursing home. He just...the guy just needs something to live for. That’s all this is about.
Yeah, and it’s pathetic. Seems like drinking always gave him more than enough to live for until now.
Go easy on the man, okay? He'll probably forget all about this ina day or two.
And then it’1l be some other demented crap, like the infomercial stuff last year. Mom and I are looking at reality, and you'd better start too. (MORE )
A home would be in his best interest -- which, let’s face it -- is more than he ever thought about with us. He never gave a shit about you or me. They peek inside the garage. Woody remains focused.
I saw you anchoring the other night. Nice job.
Thanks.
First time in the chair, right?
Kelly Ann Castillo called in sick, so I got to fill in, yeah. And apparently I didn’t stink up the place too much, so...
Tom Brokaw. The new Tom Brokaw of Billings.
I don’t know about Tom Brokaw exactly, but you know, yeah, it’s looking pretty good. I’ve paid my dues. Plus, looks like Kelly Ann's got some kind of bad infection. Then from inside the garage --
You put that heap of shit on the road, I swear to God I’1l call the police! INT. DAVID’S APARTMENT - DAY 11 David sits in his recliner drinking beer and watching a documentary about Tiger Woods.
When Earl Woods died, friends say a piece of Tiger died with him.  12 Blue (10-12-2012) 11.
My dad has always taught me these words: care and share... David notices the time and switches the channel.

Billings Chamber of Commerce director Dee Pomerantz says a new convention center could bring in upwards of five million dollars to the Magic City. But opponents, led by Councilman Reilly Tilden, claim the plan is a “Pie in the Big Sky idea" that will cost taxpayers more than it's worth. The Council is expected to debate the proposal in Monday's session. Coming up next, is it time to pull out that old umbrella? Debbie Ontiveros has your soggy work week forecast. Then in Sports, Carter brings us the story of a Hardin snowmobiler who may have lost his legs, but not his will to compete. That and more coming up after the break. Stay with us.
Ross. The phone rings. David looks at the caller ID, drops his head and answers with dread.
Hello.
David, it’s your mother.
Woody walks down the sidewalk toward the BUS STATION. Dav pulls up alongside him in his car and rolls down the wind
Dad. Dad!
Leave me alone. David guns the car ahead of Woody, stops and gets out.
Come on. Let me take you home.
I’m going to Lincoln if it’s the last thing I do. I don’t care what you people think.

Listen to me. You didn’t win anything. It’s a complete scam. So you’ve got to stop this, okay? Woody looks at David as though maybe his son is finally making sense. Then he starts walking again.  13 Blue (10-12-2012) 12.
I’m running out of time.
You don’t even have a suitcase.
I’m not stayin’ there.
I can’t let you go.
It’s none of your business.
Yes, it is. I’m your son.
Then why don’t you take me?
I can’t just drop everything and drive to Lincoln, Nebraska.

What else you got goin’ on? David blinks as he absorbs this. Even a broken clock is right twice a day. INT. WOODY AND KATE’S DRIVEWAY - DAY 13 As David puts an old suitcase of his father’s into the tr of his car, Kate lays into him.
What the hell are you doing? There’s no money!
I realize that. Woody sits in the passenger seat, seemingly oblivious to discussion.
Have you lost your marbles too? Get your father out of your car this goddamned instant. You need to help me. (MORE )
I’m the one who does all the work around here. Your father just sits there. Look at him. He’s useless. His mother spoiled him.
We'll just be gone a couple of days. Don’t worry. We'll be back before you know it. Why don’t you just enjoy the time alone? You always complain about having him around.
What about your job? David gets in the car.
I told them I was sick.
Sick in the head. I’m going to tell Ross to call you. He’1l back me up.
Sounds great. Bye, Mom. David drives away.
You’re just like your father, stubborn as a mule! Couple of lunatics!
David’s Subaru heads southeast toward Wyoming.
David and Woody drive in silence for a while before --
When you get tired, you let me know, and I’1l drive.
You can’t drive.  16 17 14.
Why not?
Because your license was suspended for drinking.
I don’t drink.
Is that right?
Just a beer now and then.
That’s true. One continuous fifty- year beer.
(pointing) I can sure as hell drive better than that moron.
-- The car continues on Interstate 90 amid the wide-open spaces of Montana.
-- A freight train travels alongside the highway. Woody stares at it like a little kid. David casts glances at hi father.

While filling up the car, David stares into space taking mental stock of his strange situation. Once he replaces t nozzle, he turns to find his father. David’s eyes follow the direction of the passenger door l open, and he spots a SALOON.
Oh, shit.
David finds Woody seated comfortably amid a gaggle of weathered afternoon DRINKERS.  18 19 Blue (10-12-2012) 15.
Jesus Christ, Dad, what are you doing here?
I was thirsty.
Good to see you’re not drinking.
Beer ain’t drinking. (downing the rest of his Coors) Let’s go.
-- The car passes through shifting landscapes and impress big cloudy skies.
-- A crew of BIKERS swarms and passes the car. -- The car passes billboards, one advertising MOUNT RUSHM INT. DAVID’S CAR - DAY 19 David smiles.
Hey, Dad.
Yeah?
How about we go see Mount Rushmore?
We don’t have time for that.
It’s just a half hour off the interstate. We’re right here.
It’s just a bunch of rocks.  Blue (10-12-2012) 16.
David and Woody have stopped their car at a PULL-OFF offe a good if slightly distant view of the presidents.
So what do you think, Dad?
Doesn’t look finished to me.
How do you mean?

Looks like somebody got bored doin’ it. Washington’s the only one with any clothes, and they’re just sort of roughed in. Lincoln doesn’t even have an ear. David takes a look -- his dad’s got a point. Woody turns away. WOODY (CONT’D) Okay, now we seen it.
Establishing.
Dark. The door cracks open, and someone sneaks in before banging into a table and crashing to the floor.
Dad? David turns on the light, jumps out of bed, and finds Woo face down and motionless.
Oh, Jesus. He rolls Woody over and sees that he’s bleeding from a na gash above the eye. David runs to the bathroom and return with a towel.
I’m all right.  Blue (10-12-2012) 16A. David presses the towel onto Woody’s forehead.  Blue (10-12-2012) 17.
You’ve been drinking.
No, I haven’t. I’m fine. Go back to bed.
David watches a DOCTOR finish dressing Woody’s wound.
All righty, that ought to do it. Give me a sec. The doctor walks out of the office.
Who you got in there?
Just an old drunk who cut his head.
Where’s my teeth?
You lost your teeth? Woody answers with a grin -- he is missing four upper fro teeth.
Did you leave them at the motel?
No.
The tavern?
I wasn’t in no tavern.
Did you leave them at the place where they serve alcohol that you don’t call a tavern?  24 Blue (10-12-2012)
Must have been when I fell by the tracks. The doctor returns, speaks to David.
Considering it’s a pretty bad head wound, his age, and history of drinking, I think we should keep him in the hospital a day or so for observation.
I don’t drink.
You hear that, Dad? We won’t be making Lincoln by Friday.
We got till Monday.
We're going to take you back home.
I’m not going home.
I can’t wait until Monday. That means I wouldn’t be back at work till Wednesday.
Sellin’ record players. (to doctor) I won a million dollars.
Congratulations. That’ll just about cover one day in the hospital. David offers a weak courtesy laugh.
Woody lies in bed like a corpse -- eyes closed, mouth The TV is on. David enters, shakes his father awake. 18. 24 slack.  Blue (10-12-2012) 18a.
I looked, but I couldn’t find your teeth anywhere.  25 Blue (10-12-2012) 19.
They’re by the tracks.
You have to be more specific than railroad tracks that run from the Atlantic to the Pacific. Listen, Mom talked to Uncle Ray and Aunt Martha. They’re going to put us up in Hawthorne over the weekend.
I don’t want to go to Hawthorne. Why can’t we just go direct to Lincoln?

Because there’s no sense going to Lincoln over the weekend. I’11 get you there Monday morning. Anyway, Aunt Martha said she’d invite all your brothers over and have a little get-together on Sunday. Mom’s coming down on the bus, maybe Ross and Marcie too. It’ll be nice.
I don’t want to go to Hawthorne.
David and Woody search the ground along tracks separating tavern from a small commercial area, including a motel.
Do you remember where you fell?  Blue (10-12-2012) 20. They keep looking. David brightens and picks something up
Okay, Dad, I found it. Here it is. (running over) Oh, wait. This isn’t yours. Woody nods and keeps looking.
I was kidding. Here. Woody takes the teeth and brushes off them off.
This ain’t mine.
I was putting you on. It’s yours.
No, it’s not.
Whose else is it going to be? See if it fits.
These ain’t my teeth.
They have to be.
I should know my own teeth. David looks at his father in disbelief and starts looking again. WOODY (CONT’D) Of course they’re my teeth. Don’t be a moron.  26 27
28 Blue (10-12-2012) 21. Woody inserts his teeth and grins. WOODY (CONT’D) Come on. Let’s go.

-- David's car passes a massive windmill farm. -- David and Woody pass a faded, pocked sign reading “Nebraska, The Good Life. Home of Arbor Day.” -- Other TBD. INT./EXT. DAVID’S CAR - DAY 27 A farm report is on the radio as David and Woody reach a RURAL CROSSROADS.
Barrows and gilts are 94 higher, averaging 74.99...
Say, turn up here.
No, we should stay on 20.
I want to show you something. Woody directs David to turn onto a gravel COUNTRY ROAD.
David’s Subaru turns now from the gravel road back onto a PAVED COUNTRY ROAD.
David is curious as Woody directs him down a desolate roa
There it is. Pull in there.  Blue (10-12-2012) 21a.
David pulls into the driveway. They get out.

They used to have a big sign with a great big cowboy on it. Must have been thirty foot tall.  30 31 32 22. David looks at the motel. Trees grow out of the windows. WOODY (CONT’D) When I was a boy, my brothers and I always wanted to come by and see the big cowboy. Real big cowboy.
Is that him? David points to a rusted sign for the RUSTLER ROOST lying amid tall weeds. The big cowboy with the buckshot-pummele face is no more than ten feet tall.
Seemed bigger then.

David’s car drives slowly into the business district, a w street with head-in parking spots filled mainly with pick trucks. The buildings -- many boarded up -- pre-date 1960 with some clearly over a century old. INT. DAVID’S CAR - CONTINUOUS 31 Woody twists around to take it all in. EXT. RAY AND MARTHA’S HOUSE - DAY 32 David stops at an old two-story house with junk cars out front. AUNT MARTHA, a lively 70, comes out to greet them.
Well, hello there, boys.
Hi, Aunt Martha. She hugs them both.
Martha.  33 Blue (10-12-2012)
Look at you, Davey. You couldn’t have been more than 15 last time we saw you.
That’s what I was saying to Dad. Long time.
Well, what have you got to say for yourself, Woody?
Nothin’.
What’d you do to your head?
Fell.
You Grant brothers sure are men of few words. INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S TV ROOM - DAY 23.
Aunt Martha leads Woody and David through the house. Seat in front of the TV are Woody’s older brother RAY and Davi
twin layabout cousins BART and COLE, too old to be living home.
Look who I found hanging around out front, Ray. Your little brother Woody.
I can see that. What’s up, Woody?
Nothing. How about you?
Not much.
Hi, Uncle Ray. Ray nods as if not entirely sure he knows who David is. stare at each other a few seconds in silence. All  Blue (10-12-2012)
You boys remember your cousin David.
(shaking hands) Hey, Bart. Cole.
Hi. Hey.
Man, it’s been a long time since we all met as kids. What’re you guys up to?
Not much.
This economy has just tore up Hawthorne, Davey. Things are hard for young men.
Yeah, I’m in the home theater and electronics business myself. Rough time, I’1l tell you that.
Cole here did some jail.
Don’t bring that up.
Bitch lied through her teeth.
I will not allow that kind of language in my house.
Sorry, Mom.
(to Woody and David) Now, boys, you sit down. You must be starving. I made sandwiches. Woody and David sit as Martha heads to the kitchen. 24.  Blue (10-12-2012)
So how long’d it take you to get here?
I don’t know. We got sort of waylaid in Rapid City. That's where Dad had his little accident.
But how long total?
Oh, couple of days, I guess.
From Billings? How far’s that?
Probably about 750 miles.
It took you two days to drive 750 miles? What are you driving, a dump truck or something?
It’s a Subaru. Outback.
Hell, I drove up from Dallas one time. That’s 850 miles. I done that in eight hours.
That’s over 100 miles an hour.
Bart was movin’.
Here you go, boys. Dig in.
Shit, two days from Montana. Sombitch must have been drivin’ in reverse.
Boys, language! 25.  34 Blue (10-12-2012) INT. RAY AND MARTHA’S DINING ROOM - DAY The reunited family sit silently in the parlor. Then --
Ray’s foot’s been’s bothering him, ain’t that right?
It’s okay. It just hurts. David notices that Woody’s been staring off into space.
Did you get that, Dad? Dad?
What?
Uncle Ray’s foot hurts.
I know.
(to Ray) Everything else good, though?
Not really. David takes a sip of the off-brand soda in his hand.
Kate says they got Ross on the news out there. Says he’s doing real good.
Yep. Yeah, he’s doing great.
Good for him. He was always quite a go-getter, wasn’t he?
Yep.
Two goddamn days from Billings! Bart and Cole laugh. 26. 34  35 36 Blue (10-12-2012) 27.
As Woody walks David along the storefronts of his early l he betrays not a shred of nostalgia.
Rottle’s Clothing used to be here. (an antiques store) That was the bank.
Must’ve changed a lot since your day. Woody doesn’t answer. They continue to walk in silence as David tries to imagine Woody’s impressions. Eventually Woody leads David across the street to --
Woody pokes his head into the service bay, where two MEXI MECHANICS work on a car.
I used to own this garage.
Own it? I thought the air compressor guy did.
Ed Pegram.
Yeah, I thought he owned it.
We were partners.
Huh. What happened?
I sold it to him.
For how much?
Eight hundred.  Blue (10-12-2012) 28.
You sold him half of a business for eight hundred dollars?
That was a lot of money back then.
You need something?
My dad here used to own this place.
Oh yeah? Woody and David enter. Woody steps to the car they’re working on and peers under the hood.
So what you fellas have going on here?
Oh, we just replacing the transmission cooler lines.
Do you know Ed Pegram?
Who?
Ed Pegram. Used to own this place too. They look at each other and shake their heads. WOODY (CONT’D) (to Small Mechanic) Glasses! You’re using the wrong wrench.
Come on, Dad. Let’s get going. (to the mechanics) Good talking to you. The mechanics stare after David and Woody as they walk aw
That moron was using the wrong wrench.  37 38 Blue (10-12-2012) 29,
They continue their stroll until happening upon the SODBU BAR. Woody stops.
Let’s see if there’s anyone I know.
Inside, Woody makes a perfunctory scan for familiar faces but it’s practically empty. *
Pretty quiet in here. David starts toward the door, but with automatic reflex W takes a seat at the bar. David reluctantly follows -- wha the hell? A perky, earthy FEMALE BARTENDER comes over.
Hi, boys. What can I get you today?
Beer.
What kind of beer you want?
Anything’s fine. Coors if you got it.
I’1l have a Mountain Dew.
Fresh out of Coors. Don’t come in * till Monday. *
Bud then. *
Bud and a Dew. *
Tom Varnik still own this place?  Blue (10-12-2012) 29a.
Never heard of him. Must be before my time.
(to David) I used to know everybody in here.  Blue (10-12-2012) 30.
Is this where you had your first drink?
No, Dad used to let me sip his beer.
So I guess you kept up that fine family tradition with Ross and me.
You liked it, as I recall.
I was like six.
A sip of beer isn’t going to kill you when you’re only six. I thought you drank. Come on, have a beer with your old man.
I’ve been trying to give it up.
What for?
I was starting to... It just wasn’t helping.
I suppose now you're okay. The bartender sets the drinks down.
Say, could I have a beer too?
You betcha.
Going to drink with my dad.

Empty bottles on the table, dimmer light from outside, an more PATRONS in the bar suggest time has passed.  Blue (10-12-2012) 31. Woody is about the same, but David is a little drunk. He finishes a beer and has another on deck.
Did you and Mom used to come here?
Sure.
I didn’t tell you that Noél and I broke up.
How's that?
Noél -- you know, the girl I've been living with for the past two years. She moved out. We broke up.
(no idea) Oh.
Maybe I should have asked her to get married, I don’t know. I just... I just never felt sure, you know what I mean? How are you supposed to know when you’re sure? Were you sure?
How's that?
How did you and Mom end up getting married?
She wanted to.
You didn’t?  Blue (10-12-2012)
I figured what the hell.
Were you ever sorry you married her?
All the time. David sips his beer, eager to take this in. WOODY (CONT’D) It could have been worse.
You must have been in love. At least at first.
Never came up.
Did you ever talk about having kids -- how many you wanted, stuff like that?
Nope.

I wanted to screw, and your mother’s Catholic, so you figure it out.
So you and Mom never actually talked about whether you wanted kids or not?
I figured if we kept on screwin’, we'd end up with a couple of you. David tries to keep from flinching.
Did you ever think about leaving her? 32.  Blue (10-12-2012)
I’d just end up with somebody else who give me shit all the time.
I’d say she’s put up with your drinking all these years.
I don’t drink that much.
You’re an alcoholic.
Bullshit.
What do you mean, bullshit? I knew you had a problem when I was eight. I used to watch you hide your booze in the garage.
You stole it. I figured it was you. You cost me a lot of money
Yeah, I poured it out. I was sick of seeing you drunk all the time.
You'd never catch your brother sneaking around like that. I served my country, I pay my taxes. It’s my right to do whatever the goddamn hell I want.
So I guess you do drink.
A little.
A lot.
All right, so I like to drink, goddammit! So what? You do what you want, and so do I. You’d drink too if you were married to your mother. (MORE )
It ain’t your job to tell me what to do, you little cocksucker! Woody gets up and leaves the bar. David blinks a few time at the outburst, slaps money on the table and runs out.
David catches up to Woody, striding down the sidewalk.
Dad?
What? Neither knows what to say for a moment, and they look awa from each other.
Shall I take you back to Ray and Martha's?
I don’t know. They look down the street, where the only light is the flashing sign for the BLINKER TAVERN. Woody starts toward the blinking light. David follows.
They enter this bar, much more active than the Sodbuster. Woody spots none other than ED PEGRAM sitting with a coup of BUDDIES and heads over.
Say, don’t you owe me a couple of bucks? It takes Ed a couple of seconds to believe his eyes.

Christ almighty, it’s Woody Grant! How the hell are you? Didn’t think I’d ever see you back in Hawthorne. Fellas, this is my old buddy Woody. Slide over, will you? Let’s make room.  4l 42 Blue (10-12-2012) 35. Ed’s about 65 and is big and rough-looking. Woody takes a seat, leaving David standing awkwardly. ED PEGRAM (CONT’D) Jesus Christ, Woody. How the hell you been?
Pretty good.
Yeah, me too. Can’t complain. Boy, long time, Woody. Long time.
Yeah.
Hi, I’m David. Woody’s son. How are you, Ed?
Davey? No shit. Last time I seen you, you was just a little shaver. How you doing there, guy? I used to give you candy bars at the garage when you was only about this high.
